author: By Maggie Haberman, Michael Gold and Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump Courts Black Voters Even as He Traffics in Stereotypes
description: The former president traffics in stereotypes about Black Americans, yet he is counting on them, and aggressively courting them, in seeking to return to the White House.
content: He has repeatedly accused three Black prosecutors investigating him of “reverse racism.” He told a gathering of Black Republicans that Black people like him because he, too, has been charged by the criminal justice system. And he has suggested that Black people relate to his mug shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mike Baker, Stella Tan, Shannon Lin, Summer Thomad, Mooj Zadie, Liz O. Baylen, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Oregon Decriminalized Drugs. Voters Now Regret It.
description: State lawmakers are about to reverse course, making the possession of hard narcotics an offense again.
content: In 2020, motivated to try a different way to combat drug use, Oregon voted to decriminalize the possession of small amounts of hard drugs including fentanyl, heroin and methamphetamine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
title: Ukraine-Backed Russian Exile Groups Stage Assaults on Moscow’s Turf
description: The attacks and drone strikes across the southern border were intended to counter President Vladimir V. Putin’s control over Russia, a leader in one of the groups said.
content: Ukraine staged a flurry of cross-border ground attacks with tanks and other armored vehicles and long-range drone strikes into Russia on Tuesday, assaults that appeared aimed at disrupting President Vladimir V. Putin’s re-election campaign messaging that the war had turned in Moscow’s favor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadja Popovich
title: The Bay Area Leads the National Shift to Electric Vehicles
description: San Jose and San Francisco had the highest E.V. adoption rate among major U.S. metropolitan areas last year.
content: California has been leading the national shift toward electric vehicles. And the Bay Area has led California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 8 Video Games to Play Next
description: Journalists at The New York Times are enjoying role-playing games, roguelikes, Metroidvanias and extraction shooters.
content: Wondering what video game to play next? Get some inspiration from the games — long and short, new and old — that New York Times journalists have been enjoying. (Unless otherwise noted, these are available on the PC and all major consoles.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Where Antisemitism and Anti-Zionism Collide
description: People spit out the word “Zionist” when they really seem to mean “Jew.”
content: Every time I write, as I did last week, that I don’t think anti-Zionism is necessarily antisemitic, I get emails from Jewish readers that are angry, disappointed or sometimes simply baffled. “Israel is the political entity through which the Jewish people exercises its natural right of self-determination and control over its own fate,” said one typical recent message. “How is singling out the Jewish people to deprive it of those rights not antisemitic?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Peyser
title: See-Through Baseball Pants Have Fans, and Brands, Pointing Fingers
description: A redesign of M.L.B.’s uniforms has put Fanatics and Nike at the center of a debate about performance versus quality in sportswear.
content: At the end of this month, Major League Baseball will officially commence its 2024 season, and with spring training already in full swing, the chatter among hard-core fans and casual observers has been unusually spirited. In theory, that would be great for M.L.B. as it seeks to expand its reach amid a prolonged decline in the sport’s popularity and cultural cachet that was offset some with a series of popular rule changes last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Bitcoin’s Winning Streak Continues
description: The cryptocurrency has recently set a series of records, extending a rapid rally that has emboldened the virtual currency industry to flex its political muscle.
content: The price of Bitcoin hovered around $72,000 on Tuesday, extending a rally that has helped mint a new crop of crypto billionaires.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Education and Experience Can Help Prisoners Achieve Parole
description: Responses to a guest essay about the plight of the older incarcerated. Also: Close call on Jan. 6; the killing of innocents; the purpose of college.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: David Mixner, Fierce Fighter for Gay Rights, Is Dead at 77
description: He persuaded Ronald Reagan to help defeat a proposed ban on L.G.B.T.Q. schoolteachers in California in 1978, and he sparred with his friend Bill Clinton over “don’t ask, don’t tell.”
content: David B. Mixner, a political strategist who played prominent roles in the anti-Vietnam War movement and in the arduous fight for gay rights, and whose decades-long influence with Bill Clinton spanned both eras, died on Monday at his home in Midtown Manhattan. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Steinhauer
title: I Used to Cringe at Self-Help Books. Until This One Changed My Life.
description: How a best-selling classic from 1992 helped me rediscover my creativity.
content: I have written about art my whole career. I find it and its creators endlessly fascinating, but I’ve always seen myself as something of a different kind — a journalist and critic, yes, but never an “artist,” with all the imaginative power that word conveys. Recently, though, I conducted a particularly poignant, intimate interview. The artist and I talked about childhood and the struggle of making oneself heard. There were tears. Afterward I had a thought: What would it be like if I were the one being interviewed? Could I be the artist, possessed of creative vision, like one of my subjects? The prospect was equally thrilling and terrifying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coco Romack
title: An Artist Who Aims to Be as Eclectic as a Tumblr Feed
description: Anthony Cudahy’s lush, figurative works are inspired, in equal parts, by news footage, family photographs and Renaissance paintings.
content: When the artist Anthony Cudahy, 34, was growing up in Fort Myers, Fla., he received plenty of encouragement from his mother, a painter herself. But he still yearned for creative peers, whom he found on the blogging site LiveJournal, on which he’d spend hours messaging with other artists. Even as his world expanded offline — he moved to Brooklyn in 2007 to study graphic design and illustration at Pratt Institute and later earned an M.F.A. in painting from Hunter College — the internet continued to inform his practice. “When I first started painting, I was thinking about the role of a painter as this collector of images, almost like you’re a Tumblr,” he says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson and Benjamin Mullin
title: Sprouts of Hope in a Gloomy Media Landscape
description: A handful of digital start-ups are finding success — so far, at least — by learning lessons from their troubled predecessors.
content: This year is looking grim for the news business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: What to Know About the Accusations Against Andrew Tate
description: The antagonistic online influencer is facing charges in two separate cases.
content: Andrew Tate, an online influencer known for his displays of wealth and his misogynistic views, is facing criminal accusations over sexual misconduct in two separate cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: A ‘Perfect Monolith’ Appears in Wales
description: A resident said he discovered the shiny, silver object on a prominent hill during his daily walk.
content: Not one to let “horrific” weather stop him, Craig Muir left his house in Hay-on-Wye in Powys, Wales, early Tuesday to take his usual walk up Hay Bluff when he spotted something large, shiny and new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Sotomayor and Barrett, Lately at Odds, Discuss Relations at the Supreme Court
description: A conversation on civics and civility included discussion of whether the court is more like a really good preschool or an arranged marriage with no possibility of divorce.
content: A week after Justice Amy Coney Barrett chastised Justice Sonia Sotomayor for choosing “to amplify disagreement with stridency” in a Supreme Court decision on former President Donald J. Trump’s eligibility to hold office, the two women appeared together on Tuesday to discuss civics and civility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Michael D. Shear
title: 5 Takeaways From Hur’s Testimony About the Biden Classified Documents Inquiry
description: A former special counsel, Robert K. Hur, faced sharp scrutiny over his conclusion that the evidence was insufficient to charge President Biden with a crime and his disparaging remarks about the president’s memory.
content: Robert K. Hur, the former special counsel who investigated President Biden’s possession of classified documents after he left the vice presidency, testified before the House Judiciary Committee on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Nebraska Lawmakers Sustain Veto of Needle Exchange Bill
description: As the harm reduction approach to illegal drug use loses favor across the country, Nebraska legislators failed on Tuesday to override the governor’s veto of a bill to provide drug users with access to clean needles.
content: Nebraska seemed poised last month to become an unlikely counterpoint to the national trend of tightening drug laws. A coalition of liberal and conservative legislators in the state passed, by a wide margin, a bill to allow local governments to establish needle exchanges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Exports Are Surging. Get Ready for the Global Backlash.
description: Increasing overseas sales of manufactured goods are helping China’s economy and creating employment, but countries from Europe to South Asia may lose jobs.
content: China’s factory exports are powering ahead faster than almost anyone expected, putting jobs around the world in jeopardy and setting off a backlash that is gaining momentum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David C. Adams, Abdi Latif Dahir and Frances Robles
title: Kenya Hits Pause on Police Deployment to Haiti
description: The African nation said it would not send a force until Haiti forms a new government after the Haitian prime minister announced his intention to resign.
content: A deployment of 1,000 Kenyan police officers to Haiti to help quell gang-fueled lawlessness is on hold until a new government is formed in the Caribbean nation, officials in Kenya said Tuesday, as leaders tried to figure out a difficult question: Who is going to run Haiti?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Senators Urge Biden to Stop Arming Israel, Citing Violation of U.S. Aid Law
description: An independent and seven Democrats argued in a letter that the administration had run afoul of a part of a law that bars military aid from going to any country that blocks humanitarian aid.
content: A group of Democratic senators urged President Biden on Monday to stop providing offensive weapons to Israel for the war against Hamas until it lifts restrictions on U.S.-backed humanitarian aid going into Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Luke Broadwater
title: Poised and Precise, Hur Enters Fray Over Special Counsel’s Report on Biden
description: Robert K. Hur defended himself in the unhurried, forceful cadence of a veteran prosecutor, delivering his responses in a flat, matter-of-fact tone.
content: The former special counsel Robert K. Hur, denounced by Democrats for his unsparing description of President Biden’s memory lapses, had one of his own during his testimony on Tuesday before the House Judiciary Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Insurance Costs Are Pushing Up Overall Inflation
description: Insurance costs are on the rise for various reasons, adding to overall inflation.
content: It is costing Americans more to protect against disaster, a development that is pushing up official inflation figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Colin
title: It’s Never Too Late to Find a New Career (a Mile Above Your Old One)
description: Patrick Milando, an accomplished French horn player, now splits his time between the orchestra pit and the cockpit, where he teaches budding pilots like he himself once was.
content: “It’s Never Too Late” is a series that tells the stories of people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: How the Special Counsel’s Portrayal of Biden’s Memory Compares With the Transcript
description: The special counsel, Robert K. Hur, accused the president last month of “significant” memory problems. The interview transcript offers context to his report.
content: A transcript of a special counsel’s hourslong interview of President Biden over his handling of classified files shows that on several occasions the president fumbled with dates and the sequence of events, while otherwise appearing clearheaded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Where Will Kyrsten Sinema’s Centrist Voters Go?
description: The Democrat-turned-independent senator from Arizona said she will not run for re-election. Some voters who supported her say they are feeling squeezed out of politics.
content: As a charter-bus operator and a die-hard independent voter in Phoenix, Bj Brooks knows a lot about changing lanes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Mitch McConnell Doesn’t Wear a MAGA Hat. I’m Not Fooled.
description: The Senate minority leader may not like the former president, but he has done more for him than many other Republican leaders.
content: Late last month, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky announced that he would leave his position as Republican leader after the November elections. He’ll depart as the longest-serving party leader in the Senate’s history. He is also the longest-serving senator in Kentucky history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: On the Tripwire of a ‘Red Line,’ It’s Often Presidents Who Trip
description: Barack Obama drew one for Syria. George W. Bush drew several, for North Korea and Iran. Now President Biden has drawn one for Israel. The hard part is figuring out what to do when they are crossed.
content: When President Biden declared over the weekend that he was drawing a “red line” for Israel’s military action in Gaza, he appeared to be trying to raise the potential cost for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as their relationship plummets to new depths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Zerwick
title: What Deathbed Visions Teach Us About Living
description: Researchers are documenting a phenomenon that seems to help the dying, as well as those they leave behind.
content: Chris Kerr was 12 when he first observed a deathbed vision. His memory of that summer in 1974 is blurred, but not the sense of mystery he felt at the bedside of his dying father. Throughout Kerr’s childhood in Toronto, his father, a surgeon, was too busy to spend much time with his son, except for an annual fishing trip they took, just the two of them, to the Canadian wilderness. Gaunt and weakened by cancer at 42, his father reached for the buttons on Kerr’s shirt, fiddled with them and said something about getting ready to catch the plane to their cabin in the woods. “I knew intuitively, I knew wherever he was, must be a good place because we were going fishing,” Kerr told me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz
title: New Federal Judiciary Rule Will Limit ‘Forum Shopping’ by Plaintiffs
description: For years, litigants have tried to cherry-pick the judges in sweeping cases on abortion and immigration. Random judge selection is about to make that harder.
content: When anti-abortion activists sued the Food and Drug Administration in 2022 seeking to overturn the approval of the abortion drug mifepristone, they filed their suit in the federal court in Amarillo, Texas, where it was all but assured that the case would be heard by Judge Matthew J. Kacsmaryk, an outspoken opponent of abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Convicting Politicians
description: As a bribery case against a U.S. senator moves forward, a look at why corruption charges are so hard to prove.
content: In the last decade, it has proved surprisingly hard to put politicians accused of corruption behind bars. Appeals courts have reversed several convictions. And juries have occasionally thought the officeholders’ behavior didn’t meet the high standard for corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Erin Nolan
title: Taxing the Rich, School Funding, Housing: N.Y. Budget Battle Begins
description: Both of New York’s legislative chambers have announced their budget proposals. They have until April 1 to hash out a spending plan with the governor.
content: What do free bus rides, new taxes on the wealthy and a stiff drink in a movie theater have in common? All three have the support of lawmakers in the New York State Legislature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Airbnb Bans All Indoor Security Cameras
description: Widespread use of indoor security cameras has raised concerns about privacy in vacation rentals, hotels, public bathrooms, locker rooms and on cruise ships.
content: Airbnb said this week that it was banning the use of all indoor security cameras in its listings worldwide, an update to its current policy allowing the devices to be installed in common areas such as hallways and living rooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Zimbabwe, After Expelling U.S. Officials, Accuses Them of Promoting ‘Regime Change’
description: American officials say their team was in the country to assess governance issues, but was detained and interrogated before being deported.
content: The government of the southern African nation of Zimbabwe detained, interrogated and deported officials and contractors working for the United States government last month, and this week accused them publicly of promoting “regime change” in their country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Audience Snapshot: Four Years After Shutdown, a Mixed Recovery
description: Covid brought live performance to a halt. Now the audience for pop concerts and sporting events has roared back, while attendance on Broadway and at some major museums is still down.
content: It was four years ago — on March 12, 2020 — that the coronavirus brought the curtain down on Broadway for what was initially supposed to be a monthlong shutdown, but which wound up lasting a year and a half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: Is This What Happens When You Build a Real Social Safety Net, Then Take It Away?
description: Americans’ economic pessimism.
content: It’s a riddle that economists have struggled to decipher. The U.S. economy seems robust on paper, yet Americans are dissatisfied with it. But hardly anyone seems to have paid much attention to the whirlwind experience we just lived through: We built a real social safety net in the United States and then abruptly ripped it apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: proviso
description: This word has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word proviso has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 1 in “The Mother Who Gave Springsteen His Rock ’n’ Roll Spirit” by Jon Pareles:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Guy Trebay, Larissa Anderson and Alyssa Moxley
title: Tuxedos Stole the Show at This Year’s Oscars
description: And they were more than a fashion statement.
content: The Times reporter and critic Guy Trebay says the Oscars aren’t just about the awards people win that night. They’re also an opportunity for stars to use the red carpet for another kind of campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The U.S. Cobbled Together $300 Million More for Ukraine
description: Also, the Biden special counsel was attacked on Capitol Hill. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The Biden administration announced today that it was sending more weapons to Ukraine, the first American aid package since the previous funding ran out in December. The delivery will include artillery rounds, armor systems and air defense interceptors, which are seen as critical for Ukraine’s defenses against Russian bombardment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: U.S.-Israeli Citizen Itay Chen Was Killed in Oct. 7 Attack, Parents Say
description: Ruby and Hagit Chen said that they expected the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and President Biden to do “everything in their power” to bring Itay’s remains and the hostages home.
content: Itay Chen, a 19-year-old U.S. and Israeli citizen thought to have been taken hostage on Oct. 7, was in fact killed that day, his parents said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne and Natalie Proulx
title: Is It Becoming More Acceptable for Men and Boys to Cry?
description: Did you watch Jason Kelce’s tearful retirement announcement? Tell us your reaction to seeing him and his brother, Travis, express their emotions so openly.
content: When was the last time you shed tears in public? Afterward, how did you feel? Were you embarrassed by your display of emotion, or relieved? Did you feel judged?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Avalanche Expert’s Death Shows Dangers of Backcountry Skiing
description: Nick Burks, 37, an avalanche forecaster and experienced backcountry skier, was killed while skiing in the Elkhorn Mountains in northeastern Oregon last week, the authorities said.
content: An avalanche forecaster was killed in an avalanche while skiing in Oregon last week, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Aaron Rodgers and Jesse Ventura Top R.F.K. Jr.’s List for Running Mate
description: Mr. Kennedy said he had been speaking with the Jets quarterback “pretty continuously” for the past month.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has recently approached the N.F.L. quarterback Aaron Rodgers and the former Minnesota governor and professional wrestler Jesse Ventura about serving as his running mate on an independent presidential ticket, and both have welcomed the overtures, two people familiar with the discussions said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron DePasquale and Alex Williams
title: Eric Carmen, Raspberries Frontman and ‘All by Myself’ Singer, Dies at 74
description: He sang on the power-pop pioneers’ 1972 breakout hit, “Go All the Way,” before launching a successful solo career as a soft-rock crooner.
content: Eric Carmen, whose plaintive vocals soared above the crunching guitars of the 1970s power-pop pioneers the Raspberries on hits like “Go All the Way,” and whose soft-rock crooning later as a solo artist propelled anthems like “All by Myself” and “Hungry Eyes,” has died. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiya Miles
title: How to Parent in a World Under Siege?
description: In her elegant essay collection, “Lessons for Survival,” Emily Raboteau confronts climate collapse, societal breakdown and the Covid pandemic while trying to raise children in a responsible way.
content: Emily Raboteau’s “Lessons for Survival: Mothering Against ‘the Apocalypse’” opens with a touch of twisted wit. Pregnant with her first child and on the way to her baby shower, she glimpses a chalk message on a sidewalk sandwich board: “The end of the world is nigh!” The moment — an announcement of impending death colliding with a celebration of imminent birth — encapsulates the tensions that propel Raboteau’s book, a soulful exploration of the fraught experience of caretaking through crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Clock Ticks for TikTok
description: Advertisers are sticking with the social media platform, even as the House prepares to vote on a bill to force the company to cut its China ties this week.
content: The warnings against TikTok aren’t letting up, with U.S. security officials saying China is using the platform to meddle in elections and lawmakers calling the video app a global threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Marnia Lazreg, Muslim Scholar Who Critiqued the Veil, Is Dead at 83
description: A Hunter College sociologist, she examined the power dynamics and difficult history of her native land from a feminist and anticolonial perspective.
content: As a young girl growing up in colonial Algeria, Marnia Lazreg was enjoined by her grandmother to wear a veil, to “protect” herself. Ms. Lazreg refused. She didn’t feel the need for such protection, and the veil wouldn’t provide it anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Cassandra Vinograd
title: Hezbollah Fires More Than 100 Rockets Into Israel, Drawing Retaliation
description: The barrage by Hezbollah was among the heaviest in the months of cross-border strikes that have fed fears that the war in Gaza could expand.
content: The Lebanese militant group Hezbollah fired more than 100 rockets into northern Israel on Tuesday morning, according to Israel’s military. It was one of the heaviest barrages in the months of cross-border strikes that have fed fears that the war in Gaza could expand to another front.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Attendees at Kansas G.O.P. Event Punch and Kick Mannequin Wearing a Biden Mask
description: The mannequin was dressed in a T-shirt that said “Let’s Go Brandon.” The county party chair said that “the mask was regrettable and removed.”
content: Kansas Republicans are coming under fire for holding a fund-raiser on Friday evening at which attendees physically assaulted an effigy resembling President Biden, according to video footage shared on social media over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Republicans target TikTok, despite Donald Trump’s objection.
content: House Republican leaders are trying to pass legislation that would force the Chinese owners of TikTok to sell the platform or face a U.S. ban on the app, even after former President Donald Trump spoke out against such a move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Is the Landing Soft? Will It Stay That Way?
description: Parsing the inflation and unemployment numbers.
content: Way back in 1973, America was experiencing a troubling rise in inflation. But George Shultz, the Treasury secretary at the time, suggested that the problem would be transitory — that the economy could have a “soft landing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlene Bauer
title: She Trusted God and Science. They Both Failed Her.
description: In “Devout,” an author who grew up in the evangelical church recounts her struggle to find spiritual and psychological well-being after a mental health challenge.
content: In “Devout,” Anna Gazmarian writes of being given a Christmas present she found impossible to keep: a pendant necklace holding a tiny seed. It was a reference to the passage in Matthew where Jesus tells his apostles that faith the size of a mustard seed can move mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Children Evacuated From Gazan Orphanage to West Bank
description: The German Embassy said it had helped a charity, SOS Children’s Villages International, move nearly 70 children from the city of Rafah to get them “out of acute danger.”
content: Nearly 70 children were evacuated from an orphanage in the southern Gazan city of Rafah and taken to the Israeli-occupied West Bank, a charity involved in the effort said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘When Mom Left’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: When Mom left when I was 4, I felt incomplete. Luckily, I had Dad and Grandma Marion. Whenever Grandma would visit, I’d put on my best pink dress, joyous to see her. Dad died when I was 11. In foster care, I was branded a “burden.” (I have cerebral palsy.) Not to Grandma Marion. She visited weekly, often bringing me chocolate cake, our favorite. As an adult, I became her caregiver and helped get her into assisted living. Now I visit her every weekend. She just turned 95. To celebrate, I brought her our favorite: a big chocolate birthday cake. — Sarah Cerio
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Young
title: Obama, More Than Dickens, Looms Over This ‘Great Expectations’
description: Vinson Cunningham’s impressive debut novel finds a watchful campaign aide measuring his ambitions on the trail of a magnetic presidential candidate.
content: As much as I pretend that I’m too conscientious, too emancipated, too Black and mostly just too lazy to succumb to a cult, the aesthetic choices I made in 2008 — when a distressed white tee featuring Shepard Fairey’s rendering of Barack Obama was an essential part of my wardrobe — remind me I ain’t that special. Still, I had company. “Great Expectations,” Vinson Cunningham’s brolic and dazzlingly written debut novel, transports us to that time, when America’s most valuable commodity was proximity — real or perceived; burgeoning or dimming — to the soon-to-be president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Wednesday Briefing: Turmoil in Haiti
description: Also, more U.S. weapons for Ukraine and a looming financial crisis for dating apps
content: Kenya said it would pause a plan to send 1,000 police officers to Haiti until the Caribbean country forms a new government. On Monday, Ariel Henry, Haiti’s prime minister, agreed to step down, once a new transitional government is formed. It is unclear when that will happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Judge Throws Out Defamation Lawsuit Against Meghan, Duchess of Sussex
description: Meghan’s half sister had accused her of making “disparaging, hurtful and false” statements in an interview with Oprah Winfrey and in a Netflix documentary series.
content: A federal judge on Tuesday dismissed a defamation lawsuit against Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, after her half sister accused her of spreading “disparaging, hurtful and false” statements in interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Shogun’ Episode 4 Recap: Fire Away
description: Lord Yabushige has managed to split his loyalties between Ishido and Toranaga. A play by younger lords will force his hand.
content: Last week’s episode dropped the ball when it came to depicting visceral combat. This week’s fired it straight at the enemy and pulped them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Yurii Shyvala
title: ‘Jamming’: How Electronic Warfare Is Reshaping Ukraine’s Battlefields
description: Drones have become a critical weapon for both sides, but a lack of coordination among troops has put Ukraine at a disadvantage.
content: The Ukrainian soldier swore and tore off his headset. His video monitor had gone blurry at first, the landscape of shattered trees and shell craters barely visible, before blacking out completely. The Russians had jammed the signal of his drone as it was flying outside the town of Kreminna in eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Amanda Holpuch
title: Andrew Tate Can Be Extradited to Britain After Romanian Trial, Court Rules
description: Mr. Tate and his brother, Tristan, were arrested on charges made between 2012 and 2015, which include allegations of sexual aggression, a spokesman said.
content: Andrew Tate, the wealth-flaunting online influencer known for his misogynistic views, and his brother, Tristan, can be extradited to Britain to face sex crime charges after their trial in Romania concludes, the Bucharest Court of Appeal said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk, Gaya Gupta and Michael Levenson
title: First Aid Ship Heads to Gaza, but Far More Is Needed
description: The maritime package of more than 200 tons of food is a welcome milestone, but not nearly enough to prevent famine, said relief officials, who called on Israel to allow more aid delivery by land.
content: A ship hauling more than 200 tons of food for the Gaza Strip left Cyprus on Tuesday morning, in the first test of a maritime corridor designed to bring aid to hundreds of thousands of Palestinians who the United Nations says are on the brink of starvation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: A Chance for Hope in Haiti’s Latest Crisis
description: Why I am hopeful — and fearful — about the country’s future.
content: Dead bodies are rotting on the streets of Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince. Clean drinking water is scarce, and a cholera outbreak threatens. Hunger looms. The outgunned police force has all but disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Open Letters: Our New Opinion-Writing Contest
description: We invite students to write public-facing letters to people or groups about issues that matter to them. Contest dates: March 13 to May 1.
content: What’s bothering you? Who could do something about it? What could you say to them that would persuade them to care, or to make change?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Police Officers Used Stun Gun on Migrant Holding Toddler, Video Shows
description: The altercation occurred at a migrant shelter in Queens following a dispute between the man and a shelter employee. New York City officials are investigating.
content: New York City officials are investigating a confrontation at a city-run shelter in Queens where police officers struck and used a stun gun on a Venezuelan migrant while he was holding his 1-year-old son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Biden Clinches Democratic Nomination as Trump Awaits
description: The president secured enough delegates to become his party’s standard-bearer after a mostly uncontested primary campaign marked by Democratic doubts.
content: President Biden clinched the Democratic nomination on Tuesday, securing enough delegates to send him into a looming rematch against former President Donald J. Trump after a mostly uncontested primary campaign that was nevertheless marked by doubts — even from supporters — over his age, foreign policy and enduring strength as a candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Anti-Trump Group of Republicans Lays Out $50 Million Plan of Attack
description: The group, Republican Voters Against Trump, will run a series of homemade videos of Americans who voted for him in the past but say they can no longer do so in 2024.
content: A Republican group dedicated to opposing former President Donald J. Trump is planning to spend $50 million to stop him through a series of homemade testimonial videos of voters who backed him in past elections but say they can no longer support him in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Israel Has No Choice but to Fight On
description: As long as Hamas maintains military power, there is no hope for peace.
content: On Saturday, President Biden warned that Benjamin Netanyahu’s approach to the war in Gaza was “hurting Israel more than helping Israel.” The Israeli prime minister replied the next day that Biden was “wrong.” The rift between the two leaders means that Israel risks losing its most important pillar of military and diplomatic support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: For Some Mammals, Large Adult Daughters, Not Sons, Are the Norm
description: Despite a common narrative that male mammals tend to dwarf female ones, fewer than half of mammalian species display that pattern, a new study suggests.
content: Female elephant seals are not delicate creatures. They are rippling tubes of muscle and blubber that can weigh more than 1,000 pounds. Still, female elephant seals are absolutely dwarfed by their male counterparts, which are typically at least three times heavier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: ‘Floor Person’
description: Do you enjoy lying on the ground every once in a while?
content: Are you a “floor person”? Do you enjoy sitting or lying on the ground, even when there’s a comfortable couch, chair or bed nearby?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Explains His Run-In (Sort of) With Trump at the Oscars
description: Why did Donald Trump go online during the Oscars to criticize Kimmel’s performance as host? Kimmel thinks he was upset because no one had mentioned his name.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: ‘Age Is Not a Problem’
description: More old(er) models walked on the runways this season, marking a step in the right direction for age representation.
content: There were many head-turning moments at the Balmain show at Paris Fashion Week, which was a love letter by the creative director Olivier Rousteing to his childhood home of Bordeaux. There were twisted gold snail shells hanging from ears and as belt buckles; there were metal handbags cast into clusters of grapes, which were later served up on rhinestone-encrusted minidresses and strapless peplum bustiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz and Clara Vannucci
title: This 1,000-Year-Old Smartphone Just Dialed In
description: An 11th-century astrolabe, a complex instrument for precisely mapping the heavens, recently turned up in an Italian museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella
title: Who Are Hamas’s Top Leaders in Gaza?
description: Israel targeted Marwan Issa, a Hamas military leader, with a strike over the weekend. He is one of three leaders of the group in Gaza who Israel says were the main planners of the Oct. 7 attack.
content: Marwan Issa, who was the target of an Israeli strike in central Gaza over the weekend, is one of three leaders of Hamas in Gaza who Israel says were the main planners of the Oct. 7 attack, which killed over 1,200 people and led to the kidnapping of about 240 others, according to Israeli officials. It remained unclear on Tuesday whether the strike had hit him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Anne Brown
title: Subterranean ‘Baby Dragons’ Are Revealed to Sneak to the Surface
description: Scientists never imagined that the blind cave salamanders called olms willingly left their caves. But at numerous aboveground springs, there they were.
content: Scientists have discovered that blind cave salamanders in northern Italy leave their underground homes to go on expeditions to the surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Brown
title: What a U.F.O. Crash Teaches Us About Our Time on Earth
description: Why did a U.F.O. allegedly crash in Roswell, N.M., of all places? In 1994 the filmmaker Bill Brown set out on a road trip to explore the 1947 incident.
content: It was 1991. I listened to “Motorway to Roswell” by the Pixies a million times, but it’s not exactly where this movie came from. Partly it was the U.F.O. paperbacks I inhaled as a nerdy kid in Lubbock, Texas, and partly it was Lubbock itself. Growing up in West Texas, I learned that the real action is in the sky: dust storms, tornadoes and the occasional mystery light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Uvalde Police Chief Announces Resignation
description: The news comes less than a week after an investigation by the city of Uvalde found that city police officers made mistakes during a 2022 mass shooting, but did not violate policy.
content: The police chief in Uvalde, Texas, who was out of town during the school shooting that left 21 people dead in May 2022, announced on Tuesday that he would step down. His resignation is the latest fallout from the turmoil in law enforcement over the length of time it took for officers to confront the gunman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Literary Magazine Retracts Israeli Writer’s Essay as Staffers Quit
description: An Israeli writer’s essay about seeking common ground with Palestinians led to the resignation of at least 10 staff members at Guernica.
content: Guernica, a small but prestigious online literary magazine, was thrown into turmoil in recent days after publishing — and then retracting — a personal essay about coexistence and war in the Middle East by an Israeli writer, leading to multiple resignations by its volunteer staff members, who said that they objected to its publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Offers ‘Ironclad’ Commitment to Allies, Defying Russia (and Trump)
description: The president hosted leaders of Poland at the White House as he sought to reassure NATO members of American steadfastness in the face of threats from Moscow and former President Donald J. Trump.
content: President Biden pledged an “ironclad” commitment to America’s allies on Tuesday as he sought to reassure NATO members that the United States would not abandon its international obligations despite the threats of aggression by Russia and disruption by his all-but-certain fall election rival, former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Maria Varenikova and Paul Sonne
title: After Ukrainian Strikes, Russia Fires Top Naval Commander
description: American officials estimated that Ukraine, a country without a traditional navy, has sunk 15 Russian ships in the past six months.
content: The Kremlin has fired its top naval commander, the biggest fallout yet from a series of devastating attacks by Ukraine on Russia’s Black Sea Fleet, according to a Ukrainian and a Western official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten and Natalie Proulx
title: To Whom Would You Write an Open Letter?
description: A politician or a celebrity? A leader of a company? A school administrator? Your mom? Use our questions below to brainstorm ideas for our contest.
content: What’s bothering you? Who could do something about it? What could you say that would persuade that person to care or to make change?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Warden Ousted From Federal Women’s Prison Plagued by Sex Abuse
description: Leaders of a Northern California prison were removed on the same day that the F.B.I. raided the troubled facility.
content: The warden of a federal women’s prison in Northern California that has long been plagued by rampant sexual abuse was ousted from his job after a raid on the facility by F.B.I. agents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: Intelligence Officials Warn of Losses for Ukraine Without More U.S. Aid
description: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, and Avril D. Haines, the director of national intelligence, described an increasingly dire situation.
content: Senior intelligence officials warned on Monday that without additional American aid, Ukraine faced the prospect of continued battlefield losses as Russia relies on a network of critical arms suppliers and drastically increases its supply of technology from China.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Watch the Way You’re Driving.Carmakers Are Watching, Too.
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 12, 2024.
content: “The ‘internet of things’ is really intruding into the lives of all Americans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yara M. Asi and Vishakha Darbha
title: Gaza Is Showing Us We Need New Tools to Measure Trauma
description: Diagnoses like PTSD aren’t sufficient.
content: As the physical toll of conflict mounts for Gazan civilians, so too does the emotional and psychological suffering. Yara M. Asi, an assistant professor at the University of Central Florida, believes that we need new language and ways to understand the depth of trauma currently faced by Palestinians in Gaza. In this audio essay, she argues that Western perspectives and diagnostics for mental health are insufficient for measuring and understanding the short- and long-term impact of sustained conflict on civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: New York Times Audio
title: Biden’s Budget and Mass Layoffs at R.N.C.
description: Plus, a problem with M.L.B.’s new pants.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Top Navalny Aide Attacked With Hammer Outside Home in Lithuania
description: Leonid Volkov, a top aide to Aleksei Navalny, was beaten and sprayed with tear gas as he was pulling up to his house in Vilnius.
content: The chief of staff to Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader who died last month in an Arctic penal colony, was attacked with a hammer and tear gas outside his home in Lithuania’s capital late Tuesday, according to Mr. Navalny’s press secretary, who said the police and an ambulance had been called to the scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: What Popular Fitness Fads Get Wrong
description: Viral online exercise challenges, like the 75 Hard or the 12-3-20, might get you in shape in the short run, but they may not help you build sustainable healthy habits.
content: A new trending workout seems to emerge every month. Each guarantees a happier, healthier, stronger and leaner you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: Smithsonian American Women’s History Museum Names New Director
description: Elizabeth C. Babcock, the chief executive of Forever Balboa Park, will start this summer, after Nancy Yao’s withdrawal.
content: Second time’s the charm?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Lehane
title: A Weekend in the Country, Roiled by a Kidnapping
description: Colin Barrett’s first novel, “Wild Houses,” follows young, desperate characters in small-town Ireland.
content: In Raymond Carver’s short story “Why Don’t You Dance?,” a man whose wife has left him places the entirety of their home on his front lawn, arranged as it was on the inside, as an act of defiant despair. A young couple, referred to only as the boy and the girl, come along and presume the man is holding a yard sale. They barter for the haunted detritus of a failed marriage, and later the girl senses what the boy never does — that their life together may one day mirror that of the man and his unseen ex-wife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Five Easy Dill Dinners
description: Ginger-dill salmon, skillet chicken with orzo, dill and feta and (frozen) fava bean stew are herbaceously springy.
content: Spring is so close I can taste it — or at least I’m trying to taste it, as I load up my grocery list with green things like arugula, scallions and leafy herbs. We’re still weeks away from peak spring produce, but you can hustle winter out the door if you lean heavily on ingredients that are available in March but are giving May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Corruption’ Review: Onstage, a Scandal’s Human Drama Is Muffled
description: A new play by J.T. Rogers goes behind the scenes of the shady “news-gathering” that rocked Rupert Murdoch’s British media empire over a decade ago.
content: “Corruption,” J.T. Rogers’s tantalizing new phone-hacking play, starts on Rebekah Brooks’s wedding weekend. In a village in the English countryside, the flame-haired power broker, one of Rupert Murdoch’s favorite tabloid editors, has drawn the cream of Britain’s political class to her celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Talks About the State of the Union and Biden’s 2024 Campaign
description: The March 12, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, a Q&A about the State of the Union and Biden’s 2024 campaign. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 9 Sunny Songs for Springing Ahead
description: To celebrate the return of daylight saving time, here’s a playlist full of songs about sunshine and daylight.
content: Is it just me, or has this winter felt never-ending? Snow, cold rain, cloudy days when the sun sets before work ends — enough already!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Hanging Out in the Boiler Room With Andre Dubus III
description: When the writer built a dream home for his family, he forgot to include one important thing: a place to write. So he found an unconventional solution.
content: The cedar-shingled house that Andre Dubus III built for his family in the seaside town of Newbury, Mass., has four levels that sprawl across 6,000 square feet, with plenty of rooms that could have made a nice writer’s office. But Mr. Dubus plies his trade down in the mechanical room, near the exercise equipment and the boiler, in a lofted space that he built himself out of plywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Alan Yuhas
title: White House Denies Biden Has Set ‘Red Lines’ for Israel-Hamas War in Gaza
description: The Biden administration repeated its warning that Israel should not attack the city of Rafah, the southernmost city in the enclave, without protections for the more than a million people sheltering there.
content: The White House denied on Tuesday that President Biden had set any “red lines” for Israel in its campaign against Hamas in Gaza but warned again that Israel should not attack the city of Rafah, the southernmost city in the enclave, without protections for more than a million people sheltering there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: Pharrell and Tyler, the Creator Remix a Classic Tote
description: The Louis Vuitton men’s creative director collaborated with the rapper to design a golf bag in the spirit of the brand’s 1930s Keepall.
content: THOUGH LOUIS VUITTON’S name is now synonymous with luxury fashion, his beginnings were remarkably humble: The designer was raised by his father, a farmer, and his mother, a milliner, in the rural town of Anchay in eastern France. In 1835, a 14-year-old Vuitton embarked — by foot — on a 280-mile, two-year pilgrimage to Paris, where he spent nearly two decades mastering the art of box making under the tutelage of a prominent malletier. Following his appointment as the official trunk maker for Napoleon III’s wife, Eugénie de Montijo, Vuitton opened his first luggage shop in 1854 near Place Vendôme, where he sold leather travel goods and canvas steamer trunks. Vuitton’s business was strong enough that in 1888, his only son, Georges, trademarked his now-signature checkerboard Damier print. The company’s steamer bag, which was intended to contain laundry on trans-Atlantic voyages, debuted in 1901; in the 1930s, the brand released the Keepall, a foldable tote, originally made from cotton canvas, that was small enough to be tucked into larger suitcases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: What a Second Biden Term Would Look Like
description: How Biden’s pitch for 2024 — and beyond — has crystallized in recent weeks.
content: President Biden gave a raucous State of the Union speech last Thursday, offering his pitch for why he should be president for a second term. It’s the clearest picture we have yet of Biden’s campaign message for 2024. But while he listed off all kinds of proposals, it’s not as easy to parse what a second Biden term might actually look like. So I sat down with my editor Aaron Retica, who had a lot of questions for me about the speech itself and what Biden would be likely to accomplish if he got another four years in the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Boeing Whistleblower Who Raised Quality Concerns Is Found Dead
description: John Barnett had accused the plane manufacturer of retaliating against him after he flagged problems he saw at Boeing’s 787 factory in South Carolina.
content: A prominent Boeing whistle-blower, a former quality manager who raised concerns about manufacturing practices at the company’s 787 Dreamliner factory in South Carolina, was found dead on Saturday with what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound, according to local officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump and Biden could formally clinch their parties’ nominations with Tuesday’s primaries.
description: There’s no question that President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump will be their respective parties’ nominees, with neither facing any credible challengers, but Tuesday’s primaries could be the ones that make it official.
content: There’s no question that President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump will be their respective parties’ nominees, with neither facing any credible challengers, but Tuesday’s primaries could be the ones that make it official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Sisson
title: In Hospitals, Affordable Housing Gets the Long-Term Investor It Needs
description: Health care systems and affordable housing developers have a mutual financial interest in helping communities live healthier.
content: Ce’Yann Irving, a mother of a 1-year-old daughter, pays $990 a month for a two-bedroom apartment on the site of a former dairy processing plant in the Central City neighborhood of New Orleans. She has amenities, like a 24-hour gym and an on-site community clinic, at arm’s reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Washington State Will Be Next Test of ‘Uncommitted’ Protest Against Biden
description: The state’s primary election on Tuesday is the latest site of a movement to reject the president over his stance on Israel, though it may be days before the results are fully clear.
content: Washington State’s primary voters will offer the next glimpse of how many Democratic voters oppose President Biden’s policy toward Israel’s war in Gaza, though it may be days before a full picture of the results is clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: ‘Barbenheimer,’ and an Early Start, Boost Oscar Ratings to 4-Year High
description: ABC’s telecast of the 96th Academy Awards on Sunday drew 19.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen.
content: The comeback of live event TV continues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Wegmans Fish Shop Stole My Concept, Merchant Claims
description: Sakanaya at the new Wegmans at Astor Place is involved in a legal dispute with a small shop, Osakana, that is a few blocks away.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at a small Manhattan fish market whose owner says the supermarket chain Wegmans copied his operation at a new store nearby. We’ll also get details on developments in some of the cases involving Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tristan Geary
title: A 20-Year-Old Transcriber Is Turning Sheet Music Into Hot Content
description: George Collier started his YouTube channel as a way to stay engaged with music during the pandemic. Now nearly a million followers tune in for his notations.
content: For some budding musicians (and even old pros), the very sight of sheet music can elicit a fight-or-flight response, bringing up painful memories of strict piano teachers and high-pressure recitals. George Collier, a 20-year-old music transcriber, is doing his part to change that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Walmart Wants to Teach Store Managers Compassion
description: The retailer brings about 2,000 managers a year to its headquarters to discuss how to relate to workers and customers, part of a U.S. corporate trend.
content: On a stormy afternoon in Bentonville, Ark., a Walmart regional manager recounted a story about a moment when his humanity came up short.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: An Artist’s Response to a Racist Mural Walks a Fine Line
description: Activists urged Tate Britain to take an offensive artwork from 1927 off its walls, but the museum instead commissioned Keith Piper to create a response.
content: For nearly 100 years, a 55-foot-long mural was the backdrop to a high-class restaurant at Tate Britain. As diners quaffed fine wine and ate expensive dishes, they could glance at the painting by Rex Whistler depicting a hunting party riding through a fantastical landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: At San Sabino, the Don Angie Team Looks to the Sea
description: Siete serves up vegan Mexican dishes, Tucci brings contemporary Italian into the Delmonico’s portfolio and more restaurant news.
content: With this new venture, the married chefs Angie Rito and Scott Tacinelli, and their partner Michael Stillman’s Quality Branded, aren’t fretting about driving business from their high-profile Italian American restaurant, Don Angie, which opened six years ago just a few doors south. “It’s different, there’s more seafood and we’re being creative with it,” Mr. Tacinelli said. The restaurant’s name is that of the patron saint of Sanza, Mr. Tacinelli’s grandfather’s native village in Campania, Italy. (He was also named Sabino.) The menu, a collaboration by the chefs, has seafood front and center, with scallop crudo, crab and mortadella dip, insalata Louie with dressed shrimp, farfalle stuffed with smoked chili crab, grilled coho salmon, and shrimp Parm with sweet and sour arrabbiata. Cured meats play an important supporting role in several dishes, as spicy capocollo dresses octopus carpaccio and ’nduja seasons stuffed mussels. As at Don Angie, the pastas are all made in-house. The room, lit with slashes of bright gold is seemingly expansive thanks to a mirrored wall. It seats 45 at mahogany tables, some set at toffee-colored leather banquettes. Another 10 seats are at a bar with more curves than the Amalfi Drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Olga Murray, Who Changed the Lives of Children in Nepal, Dies at 98
description: Her foundation rescued thousands of girls and young women from bonded slavery and secured meals and schooling for impoverished children.
content: After a six-week trip to India in 1984, Olga Murray flew to Nepal to hike through remote Himalayan villages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Michael C. Bender and Chris Cameron
title: Trump Aides, Taking Over R.N.C., Order Mass Layoffs
description: The Republican Party apparatus is undergoing a large cut with just eight months until the election.
content: Days after allies took over the Republican National Committee, Donald J. Trump’s advisers are imposing mass layoffs on the party, with more than 60 officials, including senior staff members, laid off or asked to resign and then reapply for their jobs, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Karl Wallinger, Who Sang With World Party and the Waterboys, Dies at 66
description: As a songwriter and instrumentalist as well, he blended pop and folk influences into music that helped define college radio in the 1980s and ’90s.
content: Karl Wallinger, a Welsh singer-songwriter who helped define college radio in the 1980s and ’90s as a member of the Waterboys and the founder of World Party, died on Sunday at his home in Hastings, England. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: A Broadway-Bound ‘Sunset Boulevard’ Leads Olivier Award Nominations
description: The musical, starring Nicole Scherzinger, secured 11 nominations at Britain’s equivalent of the Tony Awards.
content: A revival of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Sunset Boulevard,” starring Nicole Scherzinger as a former screen idol descending into madness, received the most nominations on Tuesday for this year’s Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Start of a Spell
description: Andrew Kingsley and Garrett Chalfin have a pitch-perfect puzzle for us.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rowan Moore Gerety
title: How Does a Tiny Mountain Town, Burned to the Ground, Come Back?
description: Lytton, British Columbia, used to draw backpackers, rafters and road-trippers until a wildfire destroyed it in 2021. Now, it’s a microcosm of how climate change is scrambling tourism.
content: Before the fire, Lytton, British Columbia, was the kind of tiny town visitors alighted upon mid-road trip, pulling off the Trans-Canada Highway to get a drink, or take in views of the Fraser and Thompson Rivers, running slate gray and deep blue more than 200 feet below. A mile up the road, also known as Highway 1, Kumsheen Rafting Resort drew 8,000 visitors annually to take half-day trips on raging rapids. Backpackers heading out on the Stein Valley Traverse stopped at the grocery store — known to locals as Ken Mart, after its owner, Ken Wong — to pick up rope, ramen and fuel before they hit the trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Southern California Oil Sheen Is Unlikely to Stem From Spill, Tests Indicate
description: Samples from an oil sheen in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Huntington Beach, Calif., were more consistent with oil that seeps naturally.
content: An oil sheen that emerged last week in the Pacific Ocean off the Southern California coast does not appear to have been caused by an oil spill, officials with the U.S. Coast Guard said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Biden Budget Lays Out Economic Battle Lines Against Trump
description: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump offer vastly different policy paths on almost every aspect of the economy.
content: President Biden in his budget this week staked out major economic battle lines with former President Donald J. Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee. The proposal offers the nation a glimpse of the diverging directions that retirement programs, taxes, trade and energy policy could take depending on the outcome of the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Juzwiak
title: A Biography of a Feminist Porn Pioneer Bares All
description: In “Candida Royalle and the Sexual Revolution,” the historian Jane Kamensky presents a raw personal — and cultural — history.
content: The idea on which Candida Royalle’s legend rests was as simple as it was brilliant. In 1984, the porn performer and eventual director-producer  co-founded Femme Productions with a single goal: to explore women’s fantasies. The hope of Royalle and partner Lauren Niemi was to change porn “from within,” as Royalle explained on a TV show, via “egalitarian” images portraying “regular, joyful lovemaking.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: How ‘I’m Just Ken’ Won the Oscars Without Winning an Actual Oscar
description: Working off ideas from Ryan Gosling and Greta Gerwig, the choreographer Mandy Moore created the crowd-pleasing number in days.
content: Sixty-two dancers. One week of cast rehearsals. Ncuti Gatwa, didn’t arrive until Friday. Slash showed up on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: F.A.A. Audit of Boeing’s 737 Max Production Found Dozens of Issues
description: The company failed 33 of 89 audits during an examination conducted by the Federal Aviation Administration after a panel blew off an Alaska Airlines jet in January.
content: A six-week audit by the Federal Aviation Administration of Boeing’s production of the 737 Max jet found dozens of problems throughout the manufacturing process at the plane maker and one of its key suppliers, according to a slide presentation reviewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Netanyahu Is Making Israel Radioactive
description: Things have gone terribly wrong in Gaza. They could get worse soon.
content: Israel today is in grave danger. With enemies like Hamas, Hezbollah, the Houthis and Iran, Israel should be enjoying the sympathy of much of the world. But it is not. Because of the way Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his extremist coalition have been conducting the war in Gaza and the occupation of the West Bank, Israel is becoming radioactive and diaspora Jewish communities everywhere increasingly insecure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. to Send $300 Million in Weapons to Ukraine Under Makeshift Plan
description: The package will keep advancing Russian troops at bay for only a few weeks, an official said.
content: The Biden administration announced on Tuesday that it was sending up to $300 million in weapons to Ukraine, the first new aid package for the country since funding ran out in late December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: The Designer Who Makes Movie Posters Worthy of Museums
description: You’ve seen Dawn Baillie’s posters for thrillers, comedies and dramas outside cineplexes. Now her work is being exhibited at Poster House in Manhattan.
content: The killer’s knife, a woman cowering before it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: The Royals Tried to Control Their Image Online. The Internet Had Other Ideas.
description: Prince William and Princess Catherine, along with Prince Harry, initially embraced social media as a way to bypass the tabloid press.
content: Trace back the digitally altered photograph of Catherine, Princess of Wales, and its roots lie in a tragedy of another Princess of Wales, Diana, whose death in 1997 predated the creation of Facebook by nearly seven years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Ticked Up Last Month, Backing the Fed’s Caution on Rate Cuts
description: Consumer prices climbed 3.2 percent last month from a year earlier, down notably from a 9.1 percent high in 2022, but still quicker than the roughly 2 percent that was normal before the pandemic.
content: Inflation sped up slightly in February on an overall basis and a closely watched measure of underlying price increases was firmer than economists had expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli and Sameer Yasir
title: Citizenship Law That Excludes Muslims Takes Effect, India Says
description: The law sparked lethal riots when it was passed. Now, after a four-year delay, it has come into force on the eve of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s re-election campaign.
content: Weeks before a national election, the Indian government has abruptly announced that it will begin enforcing a citizenship law that had remained dormant since late 2019 after inciting deadly riots by opponents who called it anti-Muslim.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 12, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 12, 2024.
content: An article on Saturday about the unclosed cases of six victims possibly linked to the Gilgo Beach serial killings incorrectly said that all the Gilgo Beach victims worked as escorts. Investigators have said only that the victims who have been identified worked as escorts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Goldsmith
title: Jack Smith and Robert Hur Are the Latest Examples of a Failed Institution
description: The regulations for special counsels have failed to accomplish a key goal.
content: On Tuesday, when the special counsel Robert Hur testifies before Congress, it will be high presidential-year political theater. This is just the latest example of the inversion of the aims of the special counsel office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Luke Broadwater
title: Special Counsel Who Investigated Biden Offers Fierce Defense of Report
description: At a hearing, Republicans peppered Robert K. Hur about his justifications for not charging the president, and Democrats rebuked him for broad assertions about Mr. Biden’s memory.
content: Robert K. Hur, the special counsel who investigated President Biden, on Tuesday fiercely defended the disparaging assessment of the president’s mental state included in his final report — and his decision not to charge Mr. Biden with a crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker and James Glanz
title: Alaska Airlines Flight Was Scheduled for Safety Check on Day Panel Blew Off
description: The 737 Max remained in service for a day after the airline’s engineers, concerned about warning lights, scheduled it to come in for maintenance. During that period, a door plug came off in flight.
content: A day before the door plug blew out of an Alaska Airlines flight on Jan. 5, engineers and technicians for the airline were so concerned about the mounting evidence of a problem that they wanted the plane to come out of service the next evening and undergo maintenance, interviews and documents show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Family Goes Missing After Heavy Rains Drench Western Australia
description: Seven people, including four children, haven’t been seen in more than a day after 5.5 inches of rain in 24 hours led to floods and closed roads.
content: Seven people are missing in Western Australia after swaths of the outback in the country’s largest and most sparsely populated state were drenched by more than 5.5 inches of rain in 24 hours over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Dating Apps Have Hit a Wall. Can They Turn Things Around?
description: The apps have changed our love lives, but they haven’t been able to convince enough young users to pay.
content: As online dating became as easy as swiping a finger across your phone screen, the companies who own apps like Tinder and Bumble became Wall Street darlings. But about a decade later, those platforms are now struggling to live up to expectations, and investors have grown frustrated and eager for something new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Republicans Can’t Restructure North Carolina Election Boards, Judges Rule
description: A panel made up of two Republicans and one Democrat ruled that a law passed last year to change the makeup of election boards is unconstitutional.
content: A bipartisan panel of three judges in North Carolina ruled that a Republican-led effort in the state legislature to restructure state and county election boards is unconstitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Conservative Party Under Fire Over Donor’s Alleged Racist Remarks
description: Frank Hester, the leading supporter of Britain’s Conservative Party, is accused of making the comments about Diane Abbott, a well-known lawmaker.
content: Britain’s governing Conservative Party was under pressure Tuesday to return more than 10 million pounds to a donor who reportedly said that Diane Abbott, a prominent lawmaker, “should be shot,” and that looking at her made him “want to hate all Black women.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: A Pop Star’s Wonky Climate Campaign
description: Adam Met wants to make it easier to build wind and solar projects.
content: There’s a major bottleneck impeding the development of new wind and solar projects in the United States: permits. File them under “seemingly boring but supremely important.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy, Kristen Soltis Anderson and Adrian J. Rivera
title: ‘He Lost Me’: Why 10 Voters Who Backed Trump in 2016 and 2020 Have Moved On
description: They cover why the former president has lost their support, why they aren’t necessarily fans of Biden and who might get their votes instead.
content: They cover why the former president has lost their support, why they aren’t necessarily fans of Biden and who might get their votes instead.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At Home With Andre Dubus III
description: When the writer built a dream home for his family, he forgot to include one important thing: a place to write. So he found an unconventional solution.

author: By Bill Brown
title: Roswell
description: Why did a U.F.O. allegedly crash in Roswell, N.M., of all places? In 1994 the filmmaker Bill Brown set out on a road trip to explore the 1947 incident.
